title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: The discomforts of Humbie had been too much for both husband  and wife — they went afterwards to Auchtertool, as we have said, and Carlyle subsequently into Annandale, to his own people.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: Mrs. Carlyle was too weak to walk in the woods with her husband, too nervous to sit the willing horse 'Fritz,' the gift of the first Lady Ashburton,  and October found the two restless natures once more in Chelsea; not, however, before a visit had been paid at Auchtertool, whence Mrs. Carlyle had written a highly original  letter of congratulation to Miss Barnes, on the announcement  of her approaching marriage.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: with his wife — that ' young girl-wife, who was so lovely and wrote poetry — God help her ! ' Having left Haddington Mrs. Carlyle writes on August 3 from Auchtertool, whither she had gone on a short visit, in language decidedly hyperbolical.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: Returned to Auchtertool, an unwise exertion made to hear Dr. Guthrie on the Sunday she passed in Edinburgh, left Mrs. Carlyle again very suffering.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: Mrs. Carlyle wrote him from Auchtertool Manse, of the

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: Arrived in Scotland, the party soon separated — Carlyle leaving his wife with her cousins at Auchtertool, and proceeding  to his sister Mary's, at The Gill, Annan — * seeking  and finding perfect solitude, kindness, and silence.'

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: My dear Mrs, Russell, — Here is another year; God help us all ! I hope it finds you better than when I last heard of you from my friends at Auchtertool.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: There was for her a solemn gladness in the midst of all the newly-awakened pain; but Carlyle was ' hag-ridden ' : a miserable few days at Auchtertool,  where he stopped to see his wife, was followed by a most uncomfortable visit to the Ashburtons in a Highland shooting- box.

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: A visit to W. E. Forster, en route for Auchtertool, occurs on July 20, and Mrs. Carlyle's account of her experiences at

title: Life of Jane Welsh Carlyle,
author: Ireland, Annie Elizabeth (Nicholson)
snippet: On hearing of the death of the old minister at Auchtertool, and of her cousin Walter Welsh's succession to the appointment  thus suddenly vacated, she writes to Mr, Carlyle —

title: Memorials of his time,
author: Cockburn, Henry Cockburn
snippet: They met near Auchtertool, in Fife, on the 22d March 1822.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: Address here; I shall find it (the letter) on my return from Auchtertool,  if I am not here before it.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: I find I cannot get off from Auchtertool.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: It has grown very cold, within the last two weeks; and I was as near catching a regular bad cold as ever I was in my life without doing it! The habit I took of waking at four at Auchtertool continued  at Morningside, where there was much disturbance from carts 'going to thelime.'

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: 2 Maggie and Mary, of Auchtertool, had been to the Isle of Wight for winter; lately home again.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: They gave me nice porridge to supper, and plenty of milk — not turned, as every drop of milk and cream at Auchtertool was; and I have slept better both the nights I have been here.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: Auchtertool: Thursday, Aug. 13.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: Auchtertool: Monday, Aug.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: Auchtertool : Monday, Aug. 3, 1857.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: On Monday  I go to Mrs. Binnie's; on Tuesday to Craigenvilla, Morningside;  and on Wednesday to Auchtertool.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: at one end of the table, looking remarkably bilious; Mrs. C. at the other, looking half dead! Mr. C. : 'My dear, I have to inform you that my bed is full of bugs, or fleas, or some sort of animals that crawl over me all night!' Now, I must tell you, Mr. C. had written to me, at Auchtertool, to 'write emphatically to Anne about keeping all the windows open; for, with her horror of fresh air, she was quite capable of having the house full of bugs when we returned; ' and so I imputed this announcement to one of these fixed ideas men, and especially husbands, are apt to take up, just out of sheer love of worrying! Living in a universe of bugs outside,  I had entirely ceased to fear them in my own house, having kept it so many years perfectly clean from all such abominations.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: Auchtertool, Bedroom: Friday, August 29.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: At the same time I shall be well pleased to return to Auchtertool on Monday, where also they are adorably kind to me, and where I have more room to turn in, in all ways.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: My aunts received me back with the heartiest welcome; and I don't think it will be possible fur me to get back to Auchtertool this week without offending them.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: Besides that I like being at Auchtertool, and they want me there for all the time I can stay.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: By the end of the next week, anyhow, I hope to get to Auchtertool again.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: The day before yesterday  I bathed at Kirkcaldy, and walked to Auchtertool after, and the fatigue was too much, and I was up to uothing but lying on the sofa all the evening, which delayed my packing till yesterday morning; and I got up at half after six, to leave time for a letter, and it was not till "prayers' were over, and the breakfast ready, that I was ready to sit down.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: Auchtertool: July 29, 1856.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: John, I fancy from Jeannie' s last letter, does not go back with him, but to Auchtertool for a little longer.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: Now that 1 know of this sister being with her, I feel in less breathless haste to fly to her rescue — can yield to Jeannie's wish, which is indeed an obligation of duty on me, with a good grace, that I would stay here over Sunday, to give her my advice about Helen; she (Jeannie) being to arrive from Auchtertool to-morrow night, to look after poor Helen, who has been very ill indeed, and I am afraid has a disease on her that, may end fatally, sooner than any of them are aware.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: However, I went next day to Auchtertool with my hand in a poultice, being still determined to ' come out of that ' on Monday, and unwilling to go without saying farewell to my poor uncle, ■whom it is likely enough I shall never see again.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: I will give you all my news so soon as I have slept a night at Auchtertool.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: — Through Kirkcaldy or Auchtertool for some days, we (Jane's last and probably first time) arrive at Linlathen, where I leave her intending for Haddington.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: My Jane at Auchtertool (manse, with cousin).

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: He will take me there and leave me; so if I go to Haddington I shall surely go to Auchtertool ; but I am not there yet.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: Jeannie and Maggie are at Auchtertool with Walter, leading a very good-for-nothivig life there according to their own account of it — engaged in perpetual tea-drinkings with ' people whom they can take no pleasure in,' and 'making themselves amends in sitting  at home with their feet on the fender, talking over the absurdities  of the said people.'

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: a Rev. Walter Welsh, Auchtertool.
